title: allow to select corpus by URL
body_html:
This is the functionality needed to connect the Laudatio Repository with ANNIS.

A link like https://korpling.german.hu-berlin.de/annis3-snapshot/#c=laudatio2:corpusridgesv1_complete can be used to select the corpus represented by a valid corpus name or external persistant identifier. An instance wide mapping determines which persistant identifier maps to which "real" corpus name.

An instance wide mapping determines which persistant identifier maps to which "real" corpus name.

title: Replace citation with a fragment based approach that allows bookmarking
Allow to define corpus sets per instance
fix #34 (plugable query builder) and introducing instance configuration
body_html:
This branch introduces the InstanceConfig which allows you to create and configure multiple "instances" of ANNIS in one deployment.

This also enables us to use plugable query builders and have a default choice per instance.
body_text:
This branch introduces the InstanceConfig which allows you to create and configure multiple "instances" of ANNIS in one deployment.

This also enables us to use plugable query builders and have a default choice per instance.
body:
This branch introduces the InstanceConfig which allows you to create and configure multiple "instances" of ANNIS in one deployment.

This also enables us to use plugable query builders and have a default choice per instance.

title: restrict metadata selection in WekaExporter
body_html: this also finally fixes #9

title: replace bigint with integer on most columns
body_html: This change results in smaller indexes without really restricting the amount of data ANNIS can import. Since most column values are now not globally unique smaller numbers will occur and enable us to use integer instead of bigint.
body_text: This change results in smaller indexes without really restricting the amount of data ANNIS can import. Since most column values are now not globally unique smaller numbers will occur and enable us to use integer instead of bigint.
body: This change results in smaller indexes without really restricting the amount of data ANNIS can import. Since most column values are now not globally unique smaller numbers will occur and enable us to use integer instead of bigint.

title: Query optimizing: transitive precedence
body_html:
This branch enables us to to some optimizing on precedence queries.

Most of the time users build up chains of precedence like this:

tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3

If tok1 and tok3 are selective but tok2 is not the PostgreSQL query optimizer can't now that tok1 and tok2 are implicitly connected with a distance of 2. The user could add these joins by hand as in

tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3 & #1 . 2 #3

but this get's almost impossible on a large number of nodes. This branch automates this tasks and propagates precedence ranges to connected nodes.
body_text:
This branch enables us to to some optimizing on precedence queries.

Most of the time users build up chains of precedence like this:

tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3


If tok1 and tok3 are selective but tok2 is not the PostgreSQL query optimizer can't  now that tok1 and tok2 are implicitly connected with a distance of 2. The user could add these joins by hand as in

tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3 & #1 . 2 #3


but this get's almost impossible on a large number of nodes. This branch automates this tasks and propagates precedence ranges to connected nodes.
body:
This branch enables us to to some optimizing on precedence queries.

Most of the time users build up chains of precedence like this:
```
tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3
```
If tok1 and tok3 are selective but tok2 is not the PostgreSQL query optimizer can't  now that tok1 and tok2 are implicitly connected with a distance of 2. The user could add these joins by hand as in
```
tok1 & tok2 & tok3 & #1 . #2  & #2 . #3 & #1 . 2 #3
```
but this get's almost impossible on a large number of nodes. This branch automates this tasks and propagates precedence ranges to connected nodes.

title: The text id should not be globally unique (only relative to document id)
Arch dependencies based on annotations
body_html:
It should be possible to use an arbitrary annotation layer as the basis of the arch_dependency view. A node_annotation_name is defined, and all nodes carrying this annotation are used instead of the actual tokens by the visualization. Pointing relations are searched for between these items. The original tokens are not shown at all.

This is useful both for Falko (e.g. dependencies between ZH1 spans, ZH2 spans etc.) and for multiple segmentations. We could define dependencies between 'dipl' segments:

tok_key:dipl

Then all nodes carrying dipl annotations are used as tokens, and all pointing relations from the triggering name space between dipl-annotated nodes are visualized as dependencies between these nodes. The value of 'dipl' is taken as the text string for the new 'token' in the visualization.

It should be possible to use an arbitrary annotation layer as the basis of the arch_dependency view. A node_annotation_name is defined, and all nodes carrying this annotation are used instead of the actual tokens by the visualization. Pointing relations are searched for between these items. The original tokens are not shown at all.

This is useful both for Falko (e.g. dependencies between ZH1 spans, ZH2 spans etc.) and for multiple segmentations. We could define dependencies between 'dipl' segments: 

tok_key:dipl

Then all nodes carrying dipl annotations are used as tokens, and all pointing relations from the triggering name space between dipl-annotated nodes are visualized as dependencies between these nodes. The value of 'dipl' is taken as the text string for the new 'token' in the visualization.

title: Administrator-defined embedded fonts
body_html:
There should be a simple way for administrators to use embedded fonts in ANNIS instances that serve Corpora with non-standard typesets. Ideally adding fonts should be done just by the administrator putting the necessary font files in a special folder. Then it should be possible to configure embedded fonts separately for:

  • the result window (where browser sans-serif is used now) and
  • the AQL box (where browser mono-space is used now).

In a second step it might be interesting to offer per-corpus result window fonts, but as a first step it might be enough to set the font globally for the whole instance.
body_text:
There should be a simple way for administrators to use embedded fonts in ANNIS instances that serve Corpora with non-standard typesets. Ideally adding fonts should be done just by the administrator putting the necessary font files in a special folder. Then it should be possible to configure embedded fonts separately for: 

the result window (where browser sans-serif is used now) and 
the AQL box (where browser mono-space is used now). 
In a second step it might be interesting to offer per-corpus result window fonts, but as a first step it might be enough to set the font globally for the whole instance.
body:
There should be a simple way for administrators to use embedded fonts in ANNIS instances that serve Corpora with non-standard typesets. Ideally adding fonts should be done just by the administrator putting the necessary font files in a special folder. Then it should be possible to configure embedded fonts separately for: 

- the result window (where browser sans-serif is used now) and 
- the AQL box (where browser mono-space is used now). 

In a second step it might be interesting to offer per-corpus result window fonts, but as a first step it might be enough to set the font globally for the whole instance.

title: Plug-able query builder
body_html: We need to support custom query builders. This could use the some plugin mechanism (JSPF) as the visualizers.
body_text: We need to support custom query builders. This could use the some plugin mechanism (JSPF) as the visualizers.
body: We need to support custom query builders. This could use the some plugin mechanism (JSPF) as the visualizers.

title: WEKA: export metadata
body_html:
The WEKA exporter should also export metadata. It should be possible to either ask for all metadata available using the configuration box at the bottom of the interface, or just individual metadata annotations. If the AQL query already includes metadata, its values should be outputted in the export, e.g.:

lemma="Hund" & pos="NN" & #1 = #2 & meta::l1_1=/f.*/

should output something like:

Hund,NN,fin
Hund,NN,fin
Hund,NN,fra

etc., with a separate column for the particular value of each metadata annotation.

Imported from Launchpad using lp2gh.

  • date created: 2012-05-08T07:51:10Z
  • owner: amir-zeldes
  • assignee: krause
  • the launchpad url was https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/996386

If the AQL query already includes metadata, its values should be outputted in the export, e.g.:

lemma="Hund" & pos="NN" & #1 = #2 & meta::l1_1=/f.*/

body:
The WEKA exporter should also export metadata. It should be possible to either ask for all metadata available using the configuration box at the bottom of the interface, or just individual metadata annotations. If the AQL query already includes metadata, its values should be outputted in the export, e.g.:

lemma="Hund" & pos="NN" & #1 _=_ #2 & meta::l1_1=/f.*/ 

should output something like:

Hund,NN,fin
Hund,NN,fin
Hund,NN,fra

etc., with a separate column for the particular value of each metadata annotation.

------------------------------------
